39234038.review:
Having played the game several years before it came out on Steam, I'm overjoyed to see the game here and even more excited after seeing the countdown. I wonder what kikiyama could be revealing after the countdown ends. Words can't describe my excitement and curiosity. This is one of the games that I kept playing for hours on end, wanting to immerse myself in the dreams of this girl.

I [i] HIGHLY	[/i] recommend that anyone new to this game that they play it completely blind. No looking up guides etc. It improves the experience  a whole lot.

This game is perfect for someone who just loves to explore and look at the scenery, walking around for hours to see what's out there. The artstyle and the music are both excellent, and the subtle undertones keep you wondering about the life of the girl who chooses to never leave her room.

Overall, a highly enjoyable experience for people who just want to explore.

10/10

PS: This game has some great fangames available online

39233446.review: Yume Nikki is an avant garde art piece masquerading as a video game.

39233411.review: One of the most beautiful art games out there, Yume Nikki is a timeless emotional experience. It's like a walking simulator with great amounts of abstract and concrete imagery which let the player project their own feelings onto the game while also trying to decipher if maybe there's a greater meaning behind this piece, which feels like the greater "goal" of this game that otherwise has no clear objectives and doesn't give the player an explicit purpose. Because of this, I think it's better not to spoil anymore, this game is best played blind. However, I think it's best to play it while you have some time on your hands and can fully immerse yourself (like a weekend where you don't have a lot to do?).

39233088.review:
Era 2011. Me hallaba en una nueva casa y sin amigos cercanos. Tenía 15 años, y 
me pasaba las tardes en Youtube. Entonces vi el glorioso vídeo de Shadow. Me
descargué el juego. Me uní al foro hispano de Yume Nikki y me tiré horas jugando.
Me creé un canal de Youtube que giraba en torno a este juego y su misticismo.
Con el tiempo he ido cambiando, quizá volviéndome más huraño y cerrado. Y cuando
no quedaba nada para animarme, siempre estaba Yume Nikki. Me recuerda que mi vida, 
en comparación a la de Madotsuki, es más feliz. Ella es una ventana a dos subconscientes:
el suyo y el nuestro. Parece que no, pero cuando lo terminas, sientes que te entiendes mejor,
a pesar de la tristeza que puede llegar a generar. Es catártico.

Yume Nikki y su desarrollo temático suponen mucho más que simple terror, o tensión. Suponen la introspección del jugador.

Mi vida no es la misma que antes de conocerlo. Artísticamente está muy bien llevado, es
opresivo, de oscuros rincones y descubrimientos miles. No te arruines esta obra mirando 
por Youtube y bájatela. Es gratis, por desgracia. Este juego es de los que se merecen pagar
por él. 

¿Recomiendo este juego? Sí. Sin dudar. Siempre. Buen desarrollo temático; algo corto mirando guía pero de duración variable sin hacerlo; directo al grano y con un lore que da para teorizar, y, aunque a veces frustrante y opresivo, cuando hallas un camino, sumamente gratificante. Una obra maestra experimental que mantiene la humildad de su motor. Ojalá pudiese pagar el juego por la inmensa cantidad de horas que me ha dado. KIKIYAMA, pon tú el precio. Gustoso vaciaré mi cartera.

39232275.review:
No se puede hablar de este juego como cualquier otro realizado con el mismo software. Creado en RPG Maker 2003 por un único usuario, Kikiyama, el propósito de Yume Nikki es llevarnos a través de un pasaje onírico del que no sabemos prácticamente nada. Bueno, más que llevarnos, nos suelta en mitad de lo desconocido y deja que seamos nosotros los que desentrañemos los enigmas que pueblan la mente de Madotsuki, una soñadora lúcida que permanece recluida en su apartamento y cuya única ventana (de ahí su nombre) a un mundo más allá del de unos pocos metros cuadrados reside en su capacidad para mantenerse consciente durante un sueño.

Lo recomendable en un principio es no usar guía. Es probable que termines necesitándola, pero de entrada, lo ideal es dejarse llevar por la inquietante atmósfera, fruto de la naturaleza impredecible y abstracta del reino de los sueños. Aunque la clave está en la exploración y no hay ningún objetivo a simple vista, sí que es posible llegar al final del juego, para lo cual es imprescindible reunir todos los efectos que encontraremos dispersos por una gran diversidad de paisajes que oscilan entre lo bello y lo perturbador. Los efectos proporcionan objetos a Madotsuki e incluso cambian parcial o totalmente la forma de su cuerpo, dándole acceso a nuevas habilidades (de las cuales, la mayoría sólo serán útiles en situaciones muy concretas, dicho sea de paso) cuando ella desee. 

Además del apartado artístico, que es asombroso para un juego realizado con RPG Maker, Yume Nikki cuenta con otro punto fuerte: la música. Si bien los temas son muy cortos y el bucle se nota a legua, aumentan significativamente el efecto del aura onírica que envuelve este juego en su totalidad. Suficiente para ponerte los pelos de punta en más de una ocasión, incluso a sabiendas de que estás en un sueño y, por lo tanto, no puedes morir.

En resumen, Yume Nikki es un título que lleva ya muchos años disponible para todo el mundo y que, por fin, ha dado el gran salto a Steam. Esto, junto al mensaje adjunto en la sección de noticias, puede hacernos pensar que el proyecto ha sido retomado y que Kikiyama aún no ha dicho su última palabra al respecto. Sin embargo, la cuenta atrás que podemos presenciar en el enlace adjunto no nos garantiza que no se trate únicamente de una nueva serie de mangas y merchandising, tal y como ocurrió la última vez que se dio este caso. Sólo podemos esperar y, mientras tanto, terminar de encariñarnos con Madotsuki y su bizarro mundo.

39232214.review:
[h1]Hacía rato que no nos veíamos, ¿eh, Kikiyama? Nos has tenido en el abandono durante mucho tiempo...[/h1]

[b]Yume Nikki[/b] acaba de llegar a Steam y yo, como terrible fan de mierda que soy, salgo corriendo cual perro baboso tras su trozo de carne. Claro que este clásico no merece explicación, es toda una superpotencia de su género y ha marcado un antes y un después en este estilo de juegos nacido en base al glorioso RPG Maker, tanto es así que inspiró a tanta gente como pudo y recibió secuelas fanmade, sucesores espirituales y todo un legado que poca gente será capaz de olvidar.

Contar la historia de [b]Yume Nikki[/b] es quizás lo más complicado de todo, puesto que su mera existencia tiene el único propósito de confundir y, posteriormente, dar lugar a diversas explicaciones y teorías con sus propias bases y contradicciones cada una. Hay una premisa común que se comparte en cada una de las interpretaciones, pero es terriblemente básica: [strike]Madotsuki[/strike] desea no salir de su cuarto y encerrarse únicamente en sus sueños, en donde explora tétricos (Y abstractos) lugares en busca de unos poderes que recolectar. Utilizando eso como base, existe una infinidad de explicaciones, cada una más bizarra, sobre qué sucede y por qué sucede lo que dentro de su mente acontece. No entraré en detalles, lo mejor es que investigues por tu cuenta y decidas qué pensar.
Jugablemente este juego es bastante débil, apenas tiene alguna mecánica por encima de lo que un título hecho en RPG Maker de manera convencional puede ofrecer. Exploramos, recolectamos poderes y los utilizamos para "avanzar" entre sueño y sueño. Es terriblemente simple, pero no creo que haga falta más. Y otra cosa que no creo que haga falta es el manga oficial que se publicó hace unos años, pues arruina bastante el misterio y suelta explicaciones bastante torpes, creo que [b]Yume Nikki[/b] es una mejor experiencia como un videojuego, sin más.

En fin, juegazo. Es un clásico de esos capaces de reunir toda una comunidad en salas de chat enormes para debatir sobre su historia, sus personajes y todo lo que ello conlleva. No tengo tanto aguante como para poder esperar 15 días para ver de qué se trata ese "nuevo proyecto". Recomendadísimo.

39230571.review:
The new translation is laughably amateurish and riddled with overly literal and awkward translations (For example, the Yuki-Onna effect becomes 'Snow Woman', which is technically not incorrect but misses the cultural reference as the Yuki-Onna is a specific type of Yokai in Japanese folklore - another example is the Fat effect, which is now just... 'Get fat,' and clashes horribly with the rest of the effect titles) as well as grammatical errors, most pertaining to capitalization (Description of both Long Hair and Poo Hair effects - 'Grow Long Hair' and 'Grow Poo Hair' vs. the Blonde Hair effect's 'Grow long, beautiful, blonde hair.') Additionally, the names of some effects were obviously translated without context - for example, the Flute effect is rendered as 'Whistle,' despite the sprite very obviously being a flute or recorder. Finally, there is at least one straight-up typo which is honestly inexcusable considering how little text this game has overall - the Midget effect is rendered as 'Miget' in the 8-bit world's UI.

The actual release itself is also quite messy, as I've found what seems to be an earlier version of the translation amongst the files in a folder named "DreamDialy" - Yes, the entire game is included twice.

Otherwise it is nice to have one of my favorite games of all time finally receive an official Western release and I'm looking forward to seeing what Kikiyama and Kadokawa do with the property together.

39230145.review:
Hey so I've been oblivious / immune to this meme for all these years and, I gotta say, I sure feel lucky to not dream of boring voids hidden behind the same ring of doors every night, and also RPG Maker is a pretty terrible environment for an exploration game! I would recommend playing any dozen random 90s adventure games that are just as surreal and more visually compelling instead! Start with The Labyrinth of Time or MTV's Club Dead or The Dark Eye (Inscape) or literally anything where you don't have to hold down a key and hear SQUEAKASQUEAKASQUEAKASQUEAKA footsteps while waiting for some impassable sprites to stop looping.

Also, making a game overtly about dreams is asinine. All games are dreams. Unlike this, most of them have substance — yes, even the walking simulators which the weebs proselytizing this meme think they're too cool for.

39230037.review:
(FAIR WARNING BEFORE YOU START: The english version currently has some sound effects missing. It's up to you to decide whether to wait for a hotfix or go on playing it!


A true and timeless classic, Yume Nikki sparked a cult fanbase that I happily have been a member of almost since it came out in 2004.

Explore the bizarre dreams of Madotsuki, as you wander through landscapes that might drive you crazy, cheer you up, make you slightly disturbed and uncomfortable, and perhaps even witness events you shouldn't have expeRIあああああああ.

The creativity behind the game has inspired a very large amount (and more to come!) of fangames, with different aspects of Yume Nikki, and different interpretations behind the very long list of fan theories of what the original game is, and what the context means.

These themes include gore, horror, hallucinatory space trips, and the list goes on.

With no main objective in the game (aside from an achieveable ending screen), exploration and interaction is everything.
Go everywhere, interact with everything, see it all, make your own meaning of the things you find.

Just make sure you don't harass the wrong creatures, they will surely make you understand why.


Sit back, get comfortable, and get ready for a strange but intriguing journey.



Should you find yourself enjoying the game but still hunger for more, I would recommend the following fangames:

- Yume 2kki: The same game, but with a VAST amount of more things to do. 
(Installing the game requires a few technical solutions as the game is made by japanese people. Expect to be patient, and be ready to google errors a lot. I couldn't get it to work personally, but it's in the horizon)

- .flow: Gory, disturbing, morbid, and a little sad.,. Excellent overall quality and pixel art.

- LCDDEM: Bright and cheery, very atmospheric, absolutely incredible music, with a tragic background. Good amount of stuff to find!
(The creator has for very curious and unknown reasons done everything he could to delete every trace of his game, citing "he's trying to forget someone in his life", but you can easily find it with google anyway)

- Yuque: Short and nice, good atmosphere. Rich and detailed events to find.

Fleshchild: Very gory, disturbing. Strong focus on manslaughter. Unfinished game, has a very sudden and abrupt ending.

- Me: Slightly amateurish, but nonetheless has a very significant amount of content to explore. Quite quirky!

There are many more fangames, but these are my favorite ones that I feel is worthwhile spending some hours in.


If you're interested in discussing theories and lore, there is a ton of videos on Youtube that can explain most of the strange findings to you. 
You can also join the [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/yumenikki/] Yume Nikki Reddit [/url] where we fans regularly post content.


Thanks for reading, and I hope you will have as much fun as we've had through the years!

39229203.review:
It brings me such joy to see Yume Nikki brought to Steam, it's regarded a classic in the Pixel Horror RPG genre and rightfully so. This game has haunted my own dreams long after I have finished playing, when it was first circulating around the net. The questions left unanswered of Madotsuki's motives, the strange beings that reside in her dreams and the history behind the locations are so fascinating to the point of madness. 

As you delve deeper and deeper into their twisted dreamscape, you are dreading what you find next and when it's all over, you are left with an overwhelming sense of loneliness. However, like all dreams, there are the occasional moments of peace. Despite how bleak the world may seem, it possesses a sense of wonderment like no other, which is why the game as a whole is so compelling.  

Playing it for the first time, I believe it's a must, to do so blind. That said, for the few items that improve mobility and events that are difficult to inititate, some guidance is needed as it is an explorative game with little direction. 

(Just try to only do so when you feel something becomes too taxing.)

Your time is your own and with that, it's a game that requires some patience to be able to get the most out of it.

Your diligence is well-rewarded with an experience that makes your question your own fears and how your inner thoughts can manifest, when left unchecked.

39227484.review:
A cult classic. It's been around a long time (14 years!) and remains my favorite game of all time. I have spent far too many hours playing this.

Gameplay revolves around wandering various abtract worlds searching for "effects" which change the player in certain ways, sometimes useful but often not. Each world by itself is pretty large, and some seem even bigger because they infinitely loop. Quite a few flow into each other, and there are many more worlds than the 12 doors in the Nexus would have you believe. Each world also has plenty of events that can take place. I won't spoil any here, but events can range from one sprite changing to you being teleported somewhere else entirely.

There IS a definite ending to this game. However, there is only one hint in the game on how to get it, and I highly recommend not searching online for how to do it, or where any effects are for that matter. It'll ruin the experience. Just trust me on this one.

Anyway, that's enough from me. Play the game; if you don't like it you'll lose maybe 5 minutes of your time, but if you decide to continue I think you will enjoy it a lot.

(also, if you like this you can also play a wide selection of fangames (yume 2kki and .flow are two of the best known))

39226895.review:
A piece of advice for newcomers - don't wander aimlessly, you WILL lose your bearings. There is some method to this madness and it lies in using landmarks to navigate. The maps often loop so pick a spot and walk up/down until you either find something neat or you loop back, then try it again left/right. Found nothing? Find another landmark and try it again. Repeat until neat things are found. It's also a good idea to do this at entryways so you can get a feel for how big the map is.

Oh, and one more thing - try not to use a walkthrough. This one's more about the journey than the destination, just take in the sights and sounds and don't spoil it for yourself. It's not for everyone but this game's one hell of a trip.

39226808.review: A decade-old game that has accumulated a cult following over the years. You play as Madotsuki, a reclusive girl who doesn't have much in her life outside of her her vivid, surreal dreams. Night after night, she goes into the dream worlds -- strange and abstract, but hiding some faint hints at her past. Long before "walking simulators" were a thing, people wandered Madotsuki's subconscious. I hope Steam release gives this forgotten little gem a new life.

39225574.review:
This game has a wide cult following, and for good reason. Plus, it's made in RPG Maker 2003.

Yume Nikki is a game from 2004, and has grown in popularity ever since. Some even speculate it to be the "grand-daddy of walking simulators". While this itself is debatable, there is no question it inspired other games such as Ib, Ao Oni, Looming, and LISA (The First). 

If you've never heard of this game before somehow, you're in for a treat- it's never too late to pick up and give it a try. In Yume Nikki you play as Madotsuki, a girl who refuses to leave your room. You instead explore the wild and wacky world of her dreams, jumping from world to world in a unique stream of consciousness. The entire game is like a massive maze with all kinds of crazy secrets to explore.

In no way is this a traditional RPG game. Instead of battling things you just.... walk around. That doesn't sound too thrilling or engaging, but it's the journey along the way that really makes it (as cliche as that sounds). You'll find a myriad of special effects you can equip to your character, strange alien type creatures that range from hostile to docile, events that range from a 1/64 chance in happening all the way up to a whopping 1/3600 chance. While the game can be rather inaccessible without the bicycle and speedglitch (the bicycle can be found in the 6th door clockwise, by the way), with some patience and lust for exploration it can really pay off.

Yume Nikki is a horror game, but it's not really about scares. It's more about the subtle atmosphere that surrounds the entire thing. The best way I've heard it described is a "crushing, depressing loneliness" that never lets up for a single second. There are some things that might make you laugh and some characters that might make you feel comfortable, but this aura of isolation and fear seems to linger on around every corner. Even in real life it lingers, as all you have to do in your room is play an extremely tiring sad game called "NASU" on your famicom.

Overall, this game is massively inspirational to me, and I definitely 100% say you should give it a shot. It's not for everyone, but either way it's definitely an experience that hasn't yet been reproduced as well. I think overall Yume 2kki (the unofficial sequel by another set of developers) is a better game, but doesn't hold the same atmosphere. I also find it kind of depressing that kikiyama themself has disappeared and now everything is outsourced to "YUME NIKKI PROJECT" which we don't even know if it follows his intent or approval for what the game has become. Mangas have been made, merchandise is sprawling out, it's kind of getting out of control. Either way bottom line, play this game at least a little. It's worth your time.

39225565.review: One of the nicest, greatest weird games out there.

Yume Nikki is a game that is better spent playing blind through. If you are thinking of playing this game, DO NOT LOOK AT YOUTUBE FOR ANY HINTS. There is no losing the game, and there is no winning the game, but if you look at youtube, you will lose a lot of the thematic feel of the game.

I REPEAT, DO NOT LOOK AT YOUTUBE OR ANY OTHER GUIDE. YOU WILL MISS OUT ON AN EXPERIENCE.

Saying that, Yume Nikki is a interactive experience following a young woman's dreams. By sifting through her dreams, you may come to conclusions about the player character's life, or you may find yourself reflecting on events in your life. I heartily reccomend this game to those who like mystery and speculation.

One of my all time favorite games, I'm very much a member of the cult following. I'm super happy to find this listed on steam along with Lisa, and I can't wait to give it another re-play!

The game is very basic. It's an exploring game where you wander around until you find things. It's very relaxing, but the lack of liniar play and any clues of what to do can be a downpoint to new players. Keep this in mind if you have never played the game. I would reccommend giving it a try even if that's not your general game style interest, as the atmosphere is one of a kind and the ambient sounds and music are amazing.

Give it a go! Maybe you'll be part of the cult following too! I LOVE it.

39472634.review:
Having played this game over a decade ago, it's good to see it coming to Steam to reach out to a broader audience. One of the few RPG Maker games that saw a finished development and bore fruit.

You play as a hikikomori named Madotsuki if I recall the name correctly. And you explore some surreal dreams. There really isn't a plot.

What I wanted to write this review was mostly to point out to the droves of people claiming it borrowed inspiration from Undertale. You have been grossly misinformed unless there was time travel at play.

Yume Nikki: 2004 (RPG Maker 2003)
Undertale: 2015 (GameMaker 1)

Give it a playthrough. And learn that just because a game has a retro feel, it doesn't associate it with Undertale. This should be compared to Earthbound, more than anything. So please, for the love of god, stop saying it took elements from Undertale.

This game is sort of abstract/trippy/relaxing/confusing/beautiful/creepy/strange, really just all over the place. You just kind of wander, interact with stuff, find effects, use them to interact with more stuff, get lost in a looping map, stare at the backgrounds, listen to the music, try to figure out what all of the stuff means, get unconfortable with your own deep thoughts, and then you shake yourself back to the real world to realize it's already time for dinner.

A perfect game for days when you're stuck at home with nothing to do, or if you just need to get your mind away from life/work/school stress.

Just remember to take breaks. Im not kidding about losing track of time.

39469283.review:
maybe if i say i recommend this game then the internet people will think im cultured and that i have good taste

yes yes hmmm brilliant game, i definitely know what im doing, why do u ask

-------

In all seriousness, this game is not for everyone. I had no fcking idea what I was doing and had to use the Wikia. But then I actually started to appreciate the game for its depth and RNG factor. If there is someone out there that truly enjoys this game for what its worth without having to look online to find locations or spoilers, you have my utmost respect.

This is NOT an easy game to get into. But once you start playing it, you realise that there is so much to it. The events that occur randomly (fcking Uboa spawn already i cant be fcked to keep grinding that lightswitch) and the subtle horror aspect, exploring the psychology of a disturbed girl and interpreting her real life based off her dreams is all incredibly interesting. 

And holy shit that ending.

The music is fucking amazing. Most visual novels or high budget games arguably cannot hope to compare with this game's soundtrack. That's not to say it sounds good, in fact, sometimes it's quite the opposite. But it is so effective at setting an ambience, at manipulating the player's thought processes and inciting different feelings. 

Art is pixel art. Nothing aesthetically pleasing to look at but sometimes very effective in what it conveys. 

The only real issue I had with the game is how goddamn useless the Puddle World is in comparison to the rest of the areas. Seriously it's an original location and it seems like the creator ran out of ideas but needed to make 12 doors to complete the circle.

Overall, an incredible experience. And holy shit, that ending.

39468511.review:
This game is an odd one indeed.
Despite being 14 year old, it is avaiable on Steam only recently. And, again, despite its age, it's still 'unfinished' (ver. 0.1).
While "extremely dark world" would led you to think otherwise, it's not a horror game. It features some of the elements you would expect from horror, but it's main point isn't to scare you. You could very loosely call this adventure game with creepy elements to it. 
It has a setting (kinda), protagonist, NPCs, but no plot (i.e. you do not have a goal, besides exploring the world).
Pros:
+Except basic controls and mechanics, it explains nothing. Very refreshing in the age of AAAs expecting every player to have a comprehension level of a games journalist.
+Atmosphere.
+Worlds are interesting and it's easy to get lost.
+Soundtrack, while simplistic, has its charm.
+Exploring the unknown may be very rewarding.
+It's free.
Cons:
-It's easy to get lost, the worlds feel enourmous.
-There is no real incentive to play, besides exploration (combined with the above this may lead to feeling of pointlessness).
This is not a game for everyone. But, because it's free, has laughably low spec requirements and is very light, I think that it's for everyone to try out.

39527520.review:
Yume Nikki, the cult classic. I played it for the first time in 2013, since then my little girl Madotsuki has always had a special place in my persona. Because of that, the ending really impacted me.

[b]PROS:[/b] 
[list]
    [*] Charismatic main character. Trust me, you will love her.
    [*] Unique, thought provoking game experience. I haven't played any other video game that has given me a similar experience. The meaning of the game, the messages it implies, everything is to the interpretation of the player. There's been many theories of what's really happening with Madotsuki but never a definitive answer. You can believe in what you want.
    [*] Incredible art style that inspired dozens of other games that came after.
    [*] Unique soundtrack.
[/list]

[b]CONS:[/b]
[list]
    [*] This game may not be for everybody. If you are not a patient person or appreciate games beyond the concept then I doubt that you will enjoy this game.
[/list]

[h1]Rating:[/h1]

[b]9.0 / Excellent.[/b] An incredible game, I'm really glad I could experience it. It may not be for everyone, but if you're at least one bit curious I think you should give it a try.

this is one of the most "not for everyone" games ever created.  you could even argue whether or not it could be considered a game at all.  for me, yume nikki is one of my favorite games of all time, because no other piece of media elicits the same feelings in me as this game does.  its bizarre, unclear, lonely, dripping in atmosphere, and i love it to bits.  even though i would never expect everyone who plays this game to like it as much as i do, i still encourage everyone to at least give it a try.  word of warning, though, have a guide at the ready if you do.  some things are so obscure and not explained youre going to need one.  plenty of guides exist online by now and for a game like this i wouldnt expect anyone to try to complete it completely blind.

39525462.review:
In this cult hit from '04, you traverse a webwork of subtly menacing dreamscapes with no clear objective, other than to absorb the heady atmosphere of Madotsuki's subconscious.  It is [i]mesmerizing[/i].  If you like the bizarre for its own sake, this is your game.  If you like exploration for its own sake, but despise the eye-rolling bait 'n' switch stories of today's walking simulators, this is your game.  The world inside Madotsuki's mind feels infinite in variety and reach.  There are a few effects (special powers) that you can't obtain without possessing others, but most of the time you are free to delve as deeply as you desire.

There is a secret ending.  If you want to see it (you'll [i]know[/i] if you do, because you'll either love or hate the game after an hour), I recommend you first obtain most of the 24 effects on your own, to maximize the "lonely dream wanderer" feel; once you've reached the limit of what you can find without help, open up a wiki and finish.

An indie masterpiece that spawned countless imitations, [i]Yume Nikki[/i] is to adventure games what K. W. Jeter's [i]Dr. Adder[/i] is to science fiction novels, or [i]Eraserhead[/i] is to horror films:  a uniquely rich experience that defies genre conventions and waking logic.

39485346.review:
I played this game many years ago. It is nice seeing it here again on Steam. The things I enjoyed the most about Yume Nikki were the surrealistic exploration mechanics and discovering new things with the effects. 
I'm not a fan of walking simulators, but Yume Nikki is an exception because I like how exploration is handled in this game. There is no hand holding. There isn't anything showing the player what he should do next. Also, it isn't trying to tell you any story (or is it? Not directly, at the very least). This game doesn't put on an air of pretentiousness, it allows you to explore it the way you want and think whatever you want about what you find.
There is really only one suggestion I would leave for anyone who wants to play this game: don't use a guide. The experience is better that way, playing with a guide kinda ruins the exploration aspect of the game which is a major point of it.

This is a fantastic Undertale fangame about a transgender girl named Yume Nikki, where you wander through an alternate universe in the hopes to collect all the powerups so you can save the world. 
The constant Undertale references got a bit annoying after a while, but overall I enjoyed this rather fleshed-out fangame.

I also found quite a few bugs in the game, like the one where you don't engage in battle with any of the enemies. I realize this game is pretty new so there are bound to be bugs, but I'd like to see this fixed in the meantime.

39608671.review:
Not everyone will enjoy this game. There is no dialogue, almost no "plot" of any sort, and no direction.

That being said, I've been a fan of this game for years, long before this official translation came out. Yume Nikki is disturbing, lonely, sad, unsettling, and scary all at the same time, and it captures the essence of dreams and nightmares perfectly. For me personally, even playing it spoiled, the experience is unforgettable.

Play it before the remake comes out. You can finish it in five hours, or even less if you look up a guide, so even if you don't like it you haven't invested too much time. It's not exactly psychological horror as the tag suggests, but it has always made me more uncomfortable than any horror game ever could. If you like it, there are hundreds of fangames out there (I recommend .flow, yume 2kki, and ME).

Spoilery Content Warnings: [spoiler] Depression, onscreen suicide. Many of the fan theories are very upsetting as well. [/spoiler]

39598710.review: To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Yume Nikki. The horror is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of psychology most of the events will go over a typical player’s head. There’s also Madotsuki’s nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into her characterisation- her personal philosophy draws heavily from Narodnaya Volya literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these dreams, to realise that they’re not just fantasies- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Yume Nikki truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn’t appreciate, for instance, the humour in Madotsuki’s existential catchphrase “...,” which itself is a cryptic reference. I’m smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Kikiyama’s genius wit unfolds itself on their monitors. What fools.. how I pity them.

39564188.review:
A part of me is upset that Yume Nikki is coming to Steam. I played it over a decade ago, found in a long forgotten forum I used to go to. You know that feeling of when you read a book, or watch a movie, and it feels intimately yours? Like you don't want to share it with anyone else? That's how I feel about Yume Nikki. It's such a unique experience, and one that I thought was deeply and personally mine, and the people's who played it in that bygone era, too.

But I know that just means it's a great experience. While I hope the fanbase doesn't become like FNAF or Undertale's, I guess I'm glad a new audience of people will be introduced to it. 

The gameplay is simple, but there's something new to uncover if you're willing to dig deep enough. There's lore that's hidden in each sprite. If you want an intense action paced game with lots of combat, this probably isn't for you. It's also kind of hard to get through without a guide, and it's very easy to get lost. But I think its worth it. Madotsuki and the other cast of characters have something special about them. 

Anyway, something something, UBOAAAAAAAAAAAAA.

39552598.review:
I've ignored Undertale for longest time. Its fandom was already running rampart, and ignoring their overexaggeration, I thought Undertale was some underwhelming and generic RPG with dull graphics. But... Not until I tried it myself. I thought I would not struggle. I thought I would not shed a single tear to a game. I thought I won't be impressed. I was all wrong... So wrong... Undertale is truly a great indie title, like nothing seen before. There needs to be more games like it.
Now let's go to PROS and CONS, shall we?

PROS:
-Fighting is (mostly) optimal. There will be many parts where its focused on alternative ways of defeating your foe without killing it. It's what makes the game unique. It requires you to be creative and think freely in decision making.
-RPG - RNG = Undertale; Fighting and dodging mechanics are fair and fun.
-Although visuals look simplistic and pixelated, they are not as limited as seen. Prepare to see impressive stuff.
-Interesting puzzles to solve. Even in fights, you have to figure out what is required to spare characters.
-Quite entertaining humor. Sometimes well-thought out, sometimes just small comedy things that makes us smile.
-Loveable characters whose biographies and backstories are scattered around the world.
-Replayability and different endings.

(Small) CONS:
-Although the game bases on choices, some can feel really lack-luster. For example, killing some characters won't affect too much to the game. Killing or sparing everyone you encounter, however, makes big differences.
-Hard-to-come-by choices. Some choices can't be uncovered without trial-and-error. Completely new players won't be able to take every tinniest detail in consideration that it will affect the fate of characters, and it can lead to fatal mistakes and unwanted choices. On brighter side, it adds up as a bonus to replayability.
-Sparing random encounters are very unrewarding and difficult. It's much easier to slay them, as its only way to gain EXP and increase max HP, which will be extremely helpful when wanting to spare major characters by tanking their attacks.
-Healing items have no limitations. Stacking on healing items will make fights easy, even better, when you can dodge majority of attacks. Even if you run out of healing items, the fights will be almost at end anyway.
-Bad currency balance and shops. Most of objects in shops can be found for free by exploring, and the OP healing items are really cheap, while the amount of gold you earn is rather big. Then, there are places that ask for way too much gold. I get that it's supposed to be a joke, but its been done more than once, it's not necessary.
-Useless items. Not counting the jokey ones, many items are just waste of gold and you can complete the game just fine without them. Some do have interesting concept (e.g. similar to in-battle stat buff items and berries from Pokemon), but, I never really seen a reason to buy and use them. Their upsides and downsides are all unbalanced. It's best to just stick to healing items.

Although seem like CONS are much bigger than PROS, but that's because constructive PROS might spoil fun. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND you try this game if you got money to spare, it can last +10 hours depending on how much you explore and/or replay, and it will turn your night into an unforgeable adventure. One more last thing: Don't let the game frighten you with its 4th wall breaking. Stay determined.

40646770.review:
Firstly, I will say that it's probably best that you play the game and experience it for yourself without much prior knowledge. Much of the game is based heavily on exploration, horror, surreal imagery and minor collecting, so the less you know about the game the better.

Generally speaking, though, Yume Nikki is a fascinating little freeware game from 2004 that has elements which have seldom, if ever been replicated since. It's a horror exploration game that has you playing as a young girl named Madotsuki as she explores the various aspects of her dreams.

The gameplay is oddly soothing in its own unique way; you walk around these bizarre worlds looking for doorways that may lead to other worlds, which may lead to strange, creepy or interesting little events, or small collectibles known as "Effects", which in turn either help the player traverse the dreams in a much more efficient manner, change Madotsuki's appearance, or occasionally act as puzzle items to unlock more parts of the game. It really does sound simple, but the good part about this is that it's a simple premise that's mixed in with loads of content.

There's a plethora of branching paths that lead to all sorts of different areas, and with the exception of a particularly aggrivating maze area, they're all pretty fun to explore and interact with. It might seem overwhelming at first, seeing as though the game starts you off with twelve main worlds to explore, but it becomes quickly apparent that the game is extremely non-linear - and with the exception of a handfull of areas, much of the game can be accessed right from the start, meaning that the player can find shortcuts and quicker routes between areas to potentially find their way towards new locations and new effects.

It's certainly rather slow-paced and not exactly action-packed, but there's a certain hypnotic quality to the game that almost throws the player in a zen-like state of horror psychadellia that is simply unique to this game. The atmosphere is rich, despite its dated graphics, and the game does a good job of conveying the feeling of an actual dream. A lot of the time, one might see something that doesn't make much sense on the surface, but has rather heavy amounts of subtext. Much like in nightmares, the truly scary part of your dream comes suddenly, or without much warning - and indeed, the nightmarish parts can be rather jarring, though not in the cheesy jumpscare sort of way. There's plenty of build-up that creates suspense, and the result is something that feels almost just as inscidious as it is scary, in that the enemies and failtstates in this game pose only to halt or slow down your exploration. Thankfully, its never too hard to get back to where you were, though it makes certain enemies a bit more frightening, and other ones down-right terrifying due to how drawn-out their attacks can be.

The game isn't perfect, as to be expected from a game made by one person in the early days of RPG Maker. As mentioned before, the graphics can be seen as dated by many, and the exploration can be hampered just a bit from the lack of diagonal movement. Of course, if you can get past these, then I highly recommend you check it out. It's free, it's packed with content - and if you finish the game wanting more, there's quite a few high-quality fangames made in the same vein as this one. It's easily one of the most influencial indie games from the mid-2000s, seeing references and homages in many modern indie games to this day, notably Undertale and LISA. If you enjoy slow-paced, unique horror games or unsettlingly surreal worlds and visuals, give it a shot.

40529316.review:
Yume Nikki [i](also known as ゆめにっき, aka Дневник сновидений)[/i] - Бродилка на RPG Maker, ставшая культовой, наверное, из за своего "Сюрреалистичного" сеттинга (Сны никогда не отличались реализмом, если кто не знал). Комьюнити, в те стародавние времена ещё не кормленое и не учёное этими вашими ундертуйлами и фнафами (2008 год на дворе был, хей!), с радостью стало устраивать мозговые штурмы вокруг того, что в игре нам рассказывается, и что вообще всё это должно было значить.
.
Главная задача в игре - Найти 24 т.н. "Эффекта", которые будут делать с вашей девочкой разные вообразимые и не очень изменения [spoiler](Вы даже научитесь прыгать и создавать свои копии, только смысла от этого, ну, не то что-бы много...)[/spoiler], в этом большом и пре|красном| мире. По пути, можно ещё не раз и не два проклясть разрабов за то, что они не сделали перевод на изученные вами вдоль и поперёк странствующих меридианов русский \ немецкий \ французский \ китайский язык(и), а так же освоить примитивные навыки ориентирования на местности в случае, если планета под вашими ногами - торообразная.
.
Думается мне, всем известно, что тяжело описать какие-либо ощущения так, что-бы тот, кто их не испытывал, тебя понял. Эта игра не является в этом плане чем-то примечательным, разве что, становится страшно представить себя на месте этой девочки, которая спит и видит, как бы навернуть ещё кружочек по пяти измерениям и заблудиться в зацикленном красно-чёрном лабиринте. [i][spoiler]В азиатской культуре, Красный - Цвет счастья.[/spoiler][/i] О да, зацикленные локации - это местная достопримечательность, и, если вы шли в одну сторону какое-то время, и вам начинает казаться, что "Где-то я эту каменюгу \ корягу \ дверь уже видел.", то можете быть уверены: Это оно.
.
Текстурки здесь весьма сносные, кровь из глаз будет идти разве что в умеренных количествах, если вам не нравится пиксельная стилистика игр. [i]HD Патча не завезли и не завезут никогда и во веки[/i]. Кому-то может понравится здешняя музыка, не имеющая ни начала, ни вменяемого конца. Общество длинное, чего почитать тут обязательно найдёте.
.
В общем, 8\12 с учётом того, [b]Что[/b] эта игра породила после себя.
.
/++\ /+-\ / -+\
\+- / \-+/ \++/
.
_\ | /_
.
Дальнейшее чтение обзора опционально, и не несёт за собой никакого смысла. Low-Dangerous Spoilers Alert.
.
[spoiler]Если вам не понравится концовка, просто мысленно дорисуйте взрыв за спиной у Мадоцуки (так зовут девочку, за которую мы играем) и сцену пафосного приземления. Именно в таком порядке. Хотя, если эта игра попалась на глаза кому-то из видео-блогеров, то, наверное, всё выше сказанное теряет смысл.[/spoiler] 
.
[spoiler]И вообще, эта игра по своим масштабам ещё скромная, и пусть вас не пугают зацикленные локации 200х200 квадратов, которые вы все должны будете топать пешочком, или, в более благоприятном случае, найденом в вырвиглазном мире велосипеде. По сравнению с тем, что эта игра породила, оригинал, предоставленный нашему обозрению - шальной порыв ветра, задающий планку фансервиса в тредновом аниме, на фоне урагана.[/spoiler] 
.
[spoiler]И да, мой вам совет: Не знакомьтесь с фангеймами (В стим не завезли), если не ознакомлены с оригиналом (Пред вашими глазами). Рискуете себе серьёзно испортить впечатление об оригинале (как это и произошло со мной) и просто можете от части не понять некоторых классических аспектов, которые сейчас используются в некоторых пиксельных хоррорах на мукере.[/spoiler]

40410330.review:
ya lo jugue y "gane" (si es que se puede llamar ganar a esta historia) antes. Una pequeña obra de arte, es hermoso en todo sentido musicalmente, artisticamente, jugabilidad. Transmite tanto sentimiento, podran llamarlo walking simulator pero eso no quita su belleza.

Todo es tan tranquilo, triste, sobrecojedor, misterioso. Las unicas tonadas alegres del juego se ven opacadas por un sentimiento tan solitario, triste, como si estubieras solo tu explorando, pues eso este juego lo logra de una manera estupenda. Derrepente te encuentras "vida" pero no dan esa sensacion, se sienten tan ajenos que solo ayudan al sentimiento de sentirte aun mas solo en este mundo de los sueños.

Artistiamente es tan interpretable pero a la vez hermoso, de por si entender los sueños de uno es complicado, imagina los de otros... pero aqui la gracia, ir descubriendo las piezas, a veces encuentras cosas alegres, otras tan desoladoras pero de a poco puedes ir tomando el hilo de que va, hasta llegar a ese final de la historia. Te vas a encontrar con mundos totalmente a oscuras, otros que solo son numeros hasta uno que es una especie de bosquejo, cada mundo contectado con otros. Todo esto da un sentimiento de haber recorrido tanto en solo una partida, haberte perdido tanto.

En jugabilidad es solor dormir, recorrer, explorar, encontrar objetos y despertar para guardar cuando encuentres que es suficiente juego por hoy. suena aburrido, pero mientras mas te pierdes en el juego, mas lo aprecias, mas te enamora hacerlo. Es como adentrarse en un tunel, cada vez es mas oscuro pero te vas acostumbrando.

En fin, Una belleza de juego en todo sentido. Transmite tanto sentimientos, soledad, tristeza, ¿esperanza?, resignacion...

40408421.review:
ベッドに入って夢の中をお散歩するゲームです。

このゲームは基本的に敵対するものはいませんが、ひとつだけ例外があります。紫の目ととがった口が特徴の通称「鳥女」です。鳥女はプレイヤー（まどつき）を見つけるとまどつきが歩くのと同じくらいの速さで追ってきて、捕まると大抵脱出不可能な空間にワープさせられます。そんなときはテンキーの９を押してほほをつねって夢から醒めましょう。

このゲームの目標らしい目標としては、エフェクトと呼ばれるまどつきが変身できるアイテムを集めることが挙げられます。そのなかでも、汎用性が非常に高いエフェクトとして「じてんしゃ」があります。これを使えば移動速度が上がって広大な夢の中をよりスムーズに移動できます。夢の中に入って広間に扉が並んでいるうち、一番下の右側にある紫色の扉の中の世界に「じてんしゃ」が落ちています。それを拾ったら後は自由に夢の中を探索しましょう！

このゲームの元となった作品として、PS1ソフト「LSD」が挙げられることがあります。こちらも「ドリームエミュレータ」というジャンルで、ゆめにっきと非常に似通ったゲームシステムであり、３Dで夢の中を自由に移動できます。
PSストアで６００円ほどで入手できるので、ゆめにっきが好きな方はこちらのプレイもおすすめします。

40405419.review:
Oh boy, I'm glad this game finally received some more mainstream attention (like Cave Story did once it started hitting consoles).

Yume Nikki may be a game created in RPG Maker, but don't be fooled, it is no RPG, in fact, it is very barebones compared to most games in general. Not that this is a bad thing, but for those who may be used to having set objectives and story-driven gameplay, I guarantee you'll dismiss Yume Nikki right off the bat as some sort of walking simulator. Truth be told, there is a lot of walking (or cycling as you'll quickly find out) to be done, because the maps in this game are incredibly large. You're bound to get lost pretty quickly!

Yume Nikki is a game about exploring the dreams of a young girl, and it's incredibly bizarre. A lot of the areas and NPC's remind me of Earthbound/Mother, to tell you the truth. Scattered throughout the worlds are various "effects" which can grant practical or purely visual powers, such as a knife (which can kill NPC's, albeit temporarily) or the ability to turn your hair blond. Finding out the practical uses of effects adds a small level of depth to the game, although a majority of effects are there just for show.

While effects are certainly interesting, the main theme of the game is simply going places and seeing the sights. You can use a guide, sure, but that ruins the excitement when you finally do encounter something new. I haven't played the game in years, and relearning how all the worlds connected and where the effects were made me feel like I was playing for the first time again.

There is a major downside though. The Steam version of Yume Nikki is somewhat buggy at the moment, but if the audio and performance issues are ironed out, and some modern features are added (such as controller support, upscaling, and the overlay), I feel this could be the version to own. The latest non-Steam version of Yume Nikki (0.10) is available for free on other websites to download and plays perfectly well (it can also be added to Steam).

40366398.review:
Yume Nikki is a strange game that's for sure, you play as Madotsuki, a young girl who turns out to be a Hikikomori, a Japanese term for someone who is very antisocial and normally don't leave their home. The game was released in 2004 created with RPG Tsukuru 2K3, the goal of the game is to explore Madotsuki's dream world to find 24 items called effects.
In the dream world, there exists a main hub called The Nexus, in The Nexus there are 12 doors leading to various lands.
These include Block World, Graffiti World, Dark World, Puddle World, Number World, Shield Folk World, Forest World,
Snow World, Candle World, Mural World, Eyeball World, and one of my favorites, Neon World. Each of these worlds are interconnected and have hidden paths and NPC's leading to even stranger worlds called deeper locations. There are too many to count, but the main ones you will be exploring include The Docks, Dense Forest, Guillotine Room, Famicom World, The Wilderness, The Mall, Ghost World, Underground World, The Sewers, and my personal favorite, The White Desert. There are actually more than just those, I would say at least double that, but there are so many easter eggs and places to explore it's all just too much to explain here, as well as an insane maze that can take you to these places called The Red Maze. You really gotta play this game to get the full experience, it's a one of a kind game that is just incredible on it's own and I assure you, you won't be dissapointed, just be aware that the entire game is based around exploration and innovation, so don't go about it like any normal game... I give it my rating of 5 Uboa's out of 5!

40225591.review:
Yume Nikki é sim tudo o que dizem dele: Um RPG extremamente psicodélico e de qualidade fantástica, principalmente se situarmos ele na época de seu lançamento original (2004).
Se você busca um RPG convencional, com pé e cabeça (com uma história linear), Yume Nikki com certeza quebra com essa expectativa, e esse é o grande charme desse jogo. Yume lhe entrega um universo de possibilidades, [spoiler]principalmente na maneira em como você conquista os 24 efeitos através das 12 portas do Nexus,[/spoiler] e "sidequests" (podemos dizer) bastante variada, com mistérios e/ou coisas perturbadoras. O game também possui um tom nostálgico, principalmente para quem jogou produções como Undertale e OFF, que possuem uma certa inspiração na aura misteriosa de Yume Nikki.
Analisando de maneira técnica, apesar dos gráficos simples, a uma primeira vista, a pixel art é muito bem trabalhada (principalmente nas poucas animações) e muitos cenários ou fundos são propositalmente encaixados no jogo para aproximar o jogador dos sentimentos da protagonista Madotsuki e contribuir para a ambientação do jogo.
Um ponto importantíssimo a ser destacado aqui é a durabilidade/gameplay do jogo. É preciso que o jogador tenha em mente que este é um jogo de exploração que vai exigir que se tenha, principalmente, paciência e curiosidade. A graça do jogo é você estar disposto a embarcar na alopração que ele é. Eu poderia dizer, de maneira simplista, que Yume Nikki é um simulador de sonhos como o LSD: Dream Emulator, mas existe um "algo a mais" nessa produção que a torna única e sombriamente maravilhosa.

Recomendo muitíssimo, se jogue.

40214506.review:
Now from what I understand of this game is that You're this little girl named Madotsuki that has to collect A LOT of this so called "effects" in Her "Dream" and to save the progress You need to write it down in Her "Diary" (which makes it Yume Nikki which is lit. Dream Diary) but there are some enemies that can try to stop You from doing so... called "Toriningen" ("Bird people" in Japanese) which are crazily hard to avoid because they are "sooo goddamn unpredictable" in their movements. Sometimes You can be lucky and they won't bother You at all (depending on if they are in the normal state or the lunatic state) other times they can pretty much punish You hard...! by forcing You to reset Your progress in coming very far (by pinching Your cheek on number 9) which means waking up in Your room and have to do it over.

MY OPINION OF THIS GAME
------------------------------
I really admire the style of this game, and the music... is okay... to a certain point when it gets rather "ANNOYING" because the soundtrack plays over and over and over... and i have to say... I like the concept, to go and find these effects that pretty much is anything... a frog, hat n'scarf and some other things... 
which gives You abilities in other worlds (because there are 12 doors in this game that leads You to different worlds) Now I've just listed out what one ability can do (the frog one) and I have only found 8 out this effects...and I'm guessing there are about 24 effects... or something similar like that...

The reason to why I'm writing about this game without even finishing it is because soon there will be a 3D reboot of this game and I'm looking forward to that one. This game is phenomenal!! Original ideas and mental gymnastics are required to make out what all this is.

it is also very fucking confusing, because these worlds have... stuff...? (not sure what to call it) that You can interact with... and I wonder what the point is...! Because I cannot for the love of Me understand what You have to do with those...!

7.5/10 is My rating for this game. It's free, so go play it and then post what You think...!

Siempre he querido jugar a este juego, pero nunca puede conseguir una versión apta para mi ordenador. Ya que llego la versión de Steam estoy feliz de probarlo, Gracias KADOKAWA. Así que empecemos con mi primer análisis largo:

Este juego muy críptico. (en palabras cortas) durante las primeras horas muchas veces no entenderás lo que estás haciendo o a donde debes ir, pero en los sueños en donde se haya un significado además del propio argumento del que se necesita de nuestra interpretación para ver algún sentido, Ese sería su mayor fuerte y lo que le dio su estado de culto en 2004. La exploración es curiosa, ya que te invita a la búsqueda de información en este mundo, varias veces los descubrimientos serán extraños o hasta algo bizarros dejando con ganas de experimentar con los efectos; algunos efectos pueden interactuar con el entorno o con otros efectos. Dándonos la opción de re-explorar mundos que ya habíamos empezado. Plantando la duda de que nos hemos perdido. Esta ha sido mi primera hora de juego ya que me he quedado atascado en un punto en el que no sé qué hacer y este sería un pequeño problema, Yume Nikki no te deja del todo en claro que efectos o elementos del entorno son interactuables para seguir sintiendo progreso. Ya que me estoy viendo en la situación de probar todos los efectos con cualquier cosa extra que vea y eso en un mundo de los sueños… Te hace desear que sea más fácil identificarlos. De momento esto será lo que he podido juagar. Sin duda las casi 4 horas me han dejado sorprendido. Esa sensación de que cada paso que avanzas es tuyo. Pocos juegos la tienen Muy recomendable, aunque sea solo experimentar todo lo mencionado anteriormente. Quizá actualice este análisis cuando haya logrado avanzar.

40052543.review:
It's nice to see many of those old rpg maker games coming here, regardless being better or worse, they served as inspiration for other games later.

Even though there sure are people that truly belive this "It's an Undertale ripoff" thing, don't be fooled by trolls that help feeding this. [b]Yume Nikki was originally released in 2004[/b] as a free game you could find around. The release date on Steam is just when it was released on this platform, making it easier to find by the general public.

Yume Nikki is a game about travelling through dream worlds, sometimes nightmare-like, while you can find "effects" that let you transform into something, helping you progress, or simply are aesthetic. It's your duty to find out what can work where.
This game is not to be rushed, in fact most times you will get lost and you'll be tempted to check out a guide. I would recommend you to do that just if you need a few more effects and you are going nuts looking for them. Some aren't obvious at all, so if you see something suspicious go try to interact with it. It can be an interesting experience if you take it easy, so [u]if you are an impatient person looking for action or horror, this game isn't for you[/u].
Also, if you like mystery games on which you can come up with your own theories, you'll like it since there is plenty of symbolism and unanswered questions.

Still it's not a game for everyone but it deserves a try.

40002703.review:
[h1]究極の迷作[/h1]
青鬼、Ibと並ぶ(であろう)三大ホラーゲームの一角。今年6月で2004年の公開から実に14年となる。
一時期は「火星ピクニック」という同人系イベントも行われていたほどの名作だ。
2018年にYumenikki Projectの一環としてSteamで公開された。現在も原作者のききやま氏のHPで最新版が配布されている。

[h1]どんなゲーム？[/h1]
このゲームは、主人公窓付きの夢の中を歩き回ってエフェクトを探すだけのゲームである。[b]エフェクトを探すだけである。[/b]
まさにそれしかないのだが、それに入る独特すぎる世界観やBGMが秀逸である。ゆめにっきにしか再現できないものだ。
世界観に関しては基本的に暗いものが多いが、ところどころで特徴的明るい世界が現れたりする。
しかし、この明るい世界もどことなく非現実的であり、夢ということを確実に忘れないものにしている。
ぼやけていて非現実的、この雰囲気とどこでも確実な印象を残しにくいBGMは、まさに起きた後に忘れてしまう夢というものを完璧に表現したものである。

[h1]人を選ぶゲーム[/h1]
このゲーム、どうしても人を選ぶ。
歩き回ることがメインとなる今作は、プレイするうえで刺激がないと面白くないという人にはお勧めできない。
FPSなどの過激性は一切なく、RPGのようなストーリー性もない。
プレイしてその面白さを理解できた人だけが最後のEDを見ることとなる。
無料なので試しにプレイしてみて、合わなかったらアンインストールすればいい。
せっかくSteamに進出したのだから、怖いもの見たさでプレイしてみるのは良いことであろう。

[h1]最後に[/h1]
2月23日にはゆめにっきの新作が出る。
そっちは有料になるが、今作をプレイしてハマった人はぜひプレイしてみてほしい。
[strike]火ピク復活しねぇかな[/strike]

39953716.review:
Vintage gaming core. This was originally released in 2002, and is one of the first "walking simulators" to exist, as well as being one of the first indie games to gain a large following, if not the first. I'm amazed it's been put on steam after all these years since the creator of the game has not said a public word since the Tohoku earthquake in 2011.

The concept of this game is simple, you are a NEET who dreams. You walk around in said dreams. If you've ever heard of LSD: Dream Emulator for the PS1, this game has a very similar concept.

I don't want to spoil anything, I think this game is best played blind, but I think what makes this game so compelling after all these years is how the feeling it generates simply cannot be replicated. While you can eventually learn how to explore the world better, there's an element of randomness to exploring. The same entrances can take you to different places, so you'll never know quite where you're going. Events are likely going to play out differently with each trip to the Dream World. Events are extremely random yet somehow make sense, different events can be pieced together to come to your own conclusions regarding what is going on inside the main character's head. This game can be extremely comforting one moment and extremely disturbing the next. It's a difficult feeling to put into words.

It's not for everyone as the game has vast stretches of nothingness, but I think if you like different experiences in gaming this game is worth a shot, it's not something I've ever seen able to be replicated elsewhere, despite multiple attempts.

This game technically never got past version 0.10 (there's still a ton of content despite that), so I'm looking forward to what this Dream Diary game has to offer.

Before you comment on my playtime, I've played the game to completion already years ago, just not on steam (yes, there is an ending, but don't worry about completing the game. Spend as much time in the game as you think you want to)

39903070.review:
This is a hard game to summarize, but an easy game to review. You should absolutely play at least *some* of it, even if you aren't sure what's going on or what you're supposed to do.

Yume Nikki (Dream Diary) is one of my earliest experiences with designers using the RPG Maker software and really making an effort to get away from formula. It's as much an experiment in just seeing what can be done with the engine as a story-telling method as anything else. It has no narrative, almost no dialogue, but miles of story delivered purely through exploration. I first encountered Yume Nikki while researching unusual RPG Maker projects for a game of my own, and like a lot of people I found the project's mystique intoxicating.

You control sleepy-eyed shut in Madotsuki, who's unwillingness to leave her home means that she must turn to lucid dreaming to pass the long days and nights. In her dreams, she can wander a vast number of intermittently connected, diverse fantasy worlds, collecting different "effects," which are kind of like transformations she can dream herself into.

And... well, that's about it, honestly. There's no real combat to speak of, a few puzzles to discover, but the vast majority of your experience with the game will be spent walking from place to place, taking in the sights. Themes begin to emerge. Recurring images start to become apparent. And *then* the fun begins. Your mind makes connections. You wonder, theorize, make guesses at the importance of different sights and sounds.

Yume Nikki is a game that inspired an entire generation of 2D styled adventure games through its approach to gameplay and storytelling, and as confusing as it might be at times, it decidedly deserves your attention for at least an hour or two. 

It might surprise you to see just what you've been playing that took its cues from Yume Nikki.

39880064.review:
Firstly, despite the release date on Steam, Yume Nikki was released for RPG Maker back in 2004. The game is not new and is very simplistic in the control scheme. As with many older RPG Maker games, you navigate in WASD directions upon invisible tiles and you interact with objects. There are definitely more complex controls possible; but since Yume Nikki is not an RPG combat game, that is mostly all you have, besides the little video game on the TV.

Further, people are randomly throwing out [i]Undertale[/i]; but, as just said above, Yume Nikki is from 2004. Undertale literally took details [i]from[/i] Yume Nikki during its own development and crafted a pretty different experience.

Secondly, this game is not normal by any means. If you are expecting a "sensible" story, progression, action, or many other typical values to video games, then you will probably not find many of them. The game is heavily focused on being surreal, being confusing as hell, and, well... that's about it.

With those two points out of the way, I will say that I actually never played Yume Nikki until recently. I had heard of it for many years but never went out of my way to play it. Not quite sure why. So the moment it popped up on Steam, I figured "Hey, you don't really have an excuse to avoid it now."

The game literally focuses on the main character going to sleep and waking up in a dream (or rather nightmare) world. There is a main hub with a bunch of doors and each one leads to a different sub-world with some specific theme around it. You might notice, upon exploring, that [spoiler]a bunch of the sub-worlds are also interconnected through a bunch of bizarre pathways[/spoiler]. The rough idea is to simply explore these areas, see what is around there, and interact with objects or other beings that exist.

Certain objects or beings will give you an "Effect" when you interact with them. These will sometimes change your looks and also allow certain actions when using them. Sometimes the actions are just cosmetic, while other times they might cause reactions in specific areas.

There are technically enemies in the game, but there is no way for you to reach a game over, so do not worry too much on that and focus more on exploring the weirdness that you encounter.

Albeit a spoiler, I will just state for newcomers that there is indeed an [spoiler]ending to the game[/spoiler], which you can reach by [spoiler]obtaining all of the Effects (24, not including the "Tutorial" one), and leaving them as the egg objects in the dream world hub and waking up to see what is different[/spoiler].

What I highly suggest to most people who are not familiar with the game is to simply go through [i]all[/i] of the doors in the main hub, explore the areas for a bit and try to see if you find different pathways around, and then consider whether you would want to keep manually exploring. If you are still interested in navigating yourself, then sure, do so, but do not get frustrated and simply drop out. If you hit a point where you get tired of it, you can pull open a guide and look into the Effects and whatever else you can look for in the game.

I spent about 3 hours myself going around and found 11 Effects before I turned to a guide to determine more information. Unless you extremely enjoy the idea of moving tile-by-tile, interacting with every single object in multiple ways, and returning to areas over and over to keep trying new interactions, then you will not likely find everything in the game on your own. I'm sure some people have, but as said above, they probably [i]really[/i] enjoyed the large amount of time navigating and testing around, which I doubt many people do.

The game is pretty absurd and a lot of the world is up to interpretation for its weirdness and what is behind it. However, depending upon other games that you have played and what you encounter in Yume Nikki, you can probably notice some things that it inspired. I can definitely tell the connections between Yume Nikki and the indie games of [i]LISA[/i], for instance. (I actually highly recommend [i]LISA: The Painful[/i] to a [i]slightly[/i] broader audience. It is dark and can be very gross and weird, but I was surprised at how much I liked it.)

In any case, Yume Nikki was an enjoyable experience for me.

39862623.review:
Игра, в которой, по сути, развитие истории отсутствует, как и самой истории в принципе
Поначалу, игра может показаться дико скучной, но это только в первые минуты.  Отсутствие сюжета компенсируется той атмосферой, царящей в игре - таинственной и слегка мрачноватой. Странные, фантастические существа, населяющие мир снов сначала вызывают недоумение, а затем - любопытство. То же можно сказать и про все 12 миров в целом. Скитаясь по этим миркам, Вы словно попадаете на выставку психоделики. А найдя первый "эффект", в некотором смысле просыпается спортивный азарт - и ради артефактов Вы начинаете тщательнее обыскивать каждый мир, попутно замечая вещи, ранее неприметные
Хочу отметить музыку, которая прекрасно вписывается в общую картину. Музыка холодная и отдающая небольшою напряжённостью - в такие настроения обычно окрашены сны. Все компоненты "игровой атмосферы" веют недосказанностью, что тоже, обычно, присутствует во снах
Самый большой минус, я думаю, заключается в скорости главной героини - она ходит очень медленно. Велосипед(один из эффектов) затемняет минус, но на него не стоит слишком надеяться, когда нужно будет применить иной эффект, так как два эффекта одновременно использовать нельзя. Придётся отключать велосипед и наслаждаться "улиточной" скоростью, а локации-то немаленькие, и не везде в них присутствуют интересные вещи - некоторые миры имеют очень большие  пустые пространства, и "ползая" по ним с черепашьей скоростью, атмосфера может вмиг разрушиться. Атмосфера, на которой, собственно, игра и держится. И как окончание:
"Yume Nikki" - это та игра, к которой лучше отложить свой скептицизм, и заставить себя пройти ещё чуть-чуть дальше, дать шанс здешней атмосфере, а потом - затянет или нет, это зависит от склада личности игрока

39825512.review:
I started this game thinking I would be entertained by it, but was disappointed in that. I expected a story with some sense of linearity, one that I could play for a certain amount of time, reach an end or conclusion, and then be satisfied that I had taken in all the content. I don't dislike the game; it is a massive twisting labyrinth full of interesting stuff. I just wasn't ready for what it was. I tried to force the game into my pre-conceived mold by looking at walkthroughs to find all of the Effects. But that's not how the game is meant to be played.

In the end, I'm glad I had some experience with the game, even if I didn't play it right (which I don't think I would have the patience for), and many of these images were extremely interesting and will stay with me for a long time. This is a prime example of ... avent gard? Yes, this is a piece of art.

At the same time, I don't get what the big deal is. There is quite a bit of bloat in it. A prime example is one of the first worlds that you will probably enter - the forest world. It's literally a ton of copy-pasted trees that look like they were pulled from the front page of RPG maker or whatever. And it's infinitely looping. Very clearly looks like an amateur loaded up RPG maker randomly put a bunch of trees everywhere and then hit the "loop" check box. There is a significant amount of content in this "game" that wastes the users time like this. They could have made the world slightly smaller and more compact, and there still would have been a ton of cool things to explore. I just don't see why they chose to dampen the experience when there is so much cool stuff to see.

Whatever the reason, it doesn't seem to hurt its reception . . . A lot of rave for this game seems to be nostalgic (it came out in 2004), and newcomers like I might not understand what it meant to people in the time that it came out.

One other minor annoyance I had is the inability to move diagonally, which makes navigating a few tunnels to be extremely irritating and "gamey."

If you're like me and want to experience everything this game has to offer, good luck. I'm not going to take the time to wander aimlessly through a lot of repetition. Even if you locate all of the Effects (the only clear goal in the game), you still won't have seen a few things. The best way may be to, after an initial blind run-around, just "spoil" the rest and read up on what others have found. [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DIjw8ys2K0M]Or, before you do that, watch someone else wander around cluelessly, so you don't have to waste any effort.[/url]

There are a lot of novel, art ideas and symbolism that are very much worthy of analysis and discussion. The anonymity and possible death of the creator elevates all of it to an even higher plane, as if we are actually exploring the dreams of a real person.

This game is an amazing work of art that is challenging at times to fully experience.

猎奇游戏经典之作，作者在给出0.09版本和一个说明文档后销声匿迹，大有“你自己感受一下”之势。而的确，这个几乎没有文字量的游戏，完完全全要靠自己去体会，它提供了一个完全客观的世界，所以任何解释都有可能变成过度解读或落入虚无主义的漩涡之中。 在我看来，梦日记像一块沉默寡言的石匠雕刻出来的玉石，你看到了他雕出来的意象，但你看不透他的心，然后恍惚之间，你发现：你看到的其实是你自己。
       这个游戏几乎没有[spoiler]"那就是有咯"[/spoiler]jump scare，也几乎没有令人不寒而栗的图片，甚至这里还有一些治愈（确信）的场景，但它依然成为了公认的猎奇游戏。我个人的感受是[spoiler]"它与素晴日第一章的终之空异曲同工，令人恐怖是的与世界的剥离感与寂寞感，毕竟这里的互动太有限了"[/spoiler]
       最后，如果卡关，请不要立刻寻找攻略，[spoiler]"虽然这游戏没攻略真的很难"[/spoiler]，你要享受这个过程.jpg
       还有这毕竟被认为是猎奇游戏，对此不擅长的人请注意

39755560.review:
*puts on hipster cap* Well I have played this before, and let me tell you it is quite the experience.

Yume Nikki is a bare-bones surreal game created with RPGMaker. You play as a young girl (Madotsuki, according to the fandom) who refuses to step outside of her bedroom. Besides the dreadfully boring video games in her room, all she can do to entertain herself is to sleep, entering into her dream world. The "goal" of the game is to explore her dreams, collecting the various effects and bringing them back to the main nexus.

Little is known about the creator, and even less is known about the game's story. Yume Nikki lives very much by the philosophy of "Show, Don't Tell". There is no dialogue, music is limited to short sound bytes on loop, and the graphics look like something out of the 16-bit era. Despite all of this, Yume Nikki still managed to gather an almost cult-like following; the amount of fan work and theories created for Yume Nikki is truly astounding.

Plenty of games try to capture the beauty and wonder of our dreams, but the reality is they can also be ugly and painful experiences, dredging up our deepest subconscious fears and desires. Yume Nikki refuses to shy away from the dark and the strange, understanding that this what gives our dreams meaning. Like any abstract art piece, it is impossible to place a singular meaning on anything in Yume Nikki. Everyone will interpret and relate to its events differently, and perhaps this is the crux of what let Yume Nikki gather its cult following.

Its greatest strength is also its greatest weakness. The complete lack of direction is not exactly user friendly. This game does not hold your hand. There is no map, so the only way to figure out where to go is to get hopelessly lost many times as you explore the strange worlds behind each nexus door. It will be tempting to simply look up a guide, and I must admit I was guilty of watching a play-through myself for some parts. Indeed, completing the game without looking anything up is an achievement in itself.  However, the game was meant to be played, not watched. The joy (and sometimes terror) of discovery makes the experience worth experiencing. After you've given the game a proper playing, THEN you should look up all the stuff you inevitably missed. Cough cough [spoiler]Uboa[/spoiler] cough cough.

With that in mind, I humbly offer some advice to make your experience a bit more palatable. Feel free to ignore this if you wish to remain completely spoiler-free.

1) Know the controls! They are not explained very well in the game.

Arrow keys: Movement
Z: Accept; interact with objects (also Enter, Spacebar)
X: Cancel; open the game menu (also C, V, B, N, Insert)
1: Use an effect’s ability
3: Cancel an effect’s ability
5: Drop an effect on the ground (only in the Nexus)
9: Pinch yourself to wake up and return to the real world. This one is especially important to remember, as sometimes you may find yourself in a dead-end zone leaving this as your only means of escape.

2) Each time you wake up, make sure to use the desk In the real world to save your progress.

3) Be thorough. Many of the dream worlds are expansive, with few landmarks. However, many of them also warp at each end, meaning if you walk in a straight line you will eventually return to where you started. You can use this to your advantage while mapping out the more expansive zones. Take note of interesting landmarks that you can use for future exploration. It might be helpful to keep some scratch paper handy if you have a bad memory like me.

4) Interact with everything. If you see anything that looks strange or out of place, give it a poke. There are few enemies in the game, and nothing can actually kill you. Sometimes that creepy object might be the ticket to transport you into a new area. Also, try using different effects in different situations. You may find they have useful properties.

5) Search for the bicycle effect first, it will make exploration much easier as it greatly increases your movement speed. You can find the bike effect in [spoiler]the zone behind the right door at the bottom-most side of the nexus[/spoiler]. I will leave locating it to you.


Well, what are you waiting for? Give this game a try, you have nothing to lose! Except, maybe your sanity. Eh, you didn't really need that anyway.

39750163.review:
梦：不可名状。
昨天在官网下中文版玩了一会儿，其实并没有我预想中那么的致郁。[spoiler]也可说从致郁程度来说，没有哪个游戏是比真实世界更致郁的了吧（笑）。[/spoiler]
我冷静思考，觉得这只是一个制作者无心之作，粗暴的冲突色，涂鸦式的贴图，直接堆叠的前景与背景。
但，正是这种毫无逻辑的配方，营造出了难以描述的诡异。
也有人说，网上的那些解读是过度解读了，比如树木只用尖头的，是通过尖锐来暗示威胁。我觉得作者也许真的只是，想做一个气氛恐怖阴森的游戏，又觉得尖头的树符合这种氛围，于是就用了。也许他也没想过通过尖锐来映射什么，只是看到了，觉得不错，就用了。从某种意义来说，它确实表明了制作者是有意为之。
碰巧最近读到了一些现代艺术，从古典派严格的绘画规则，到抽象派与表现艺术注重个人的表达，通俗的来讲，就是艺术更随心所欲了，抛开了一些理性的东西，传达出更个体、更差异化的一种感受。
梦日记就是类似的感觉，他没有明确的讲述一个什么事儿，一个世界观，他就像真实的梦境一样杂乱无章，没有前因后果。
还有人说，它很像克苏鲁，你只看到了黑暗，便联想到不好的事情。这些事甚至没有一个具体的形状，就是萦绕在你的脑海中，他和最原始的理智一样，是一种原始的恐怖。

我玩完这个游戏也没有特别害怕，就是觉得它的制作没有特别讲究，游戏很零碎。
但当我关了灯，看见灯管残留的微弱影子，看到书橱里一动不动的模型，看到没有完全被窗帘遮住的夜色，我听到墙上的钟滴答滴答滴答。
我闭上眼，想起附窗子的游戏机里，没接到果子，红色的画面。
我在游戏里玩了一个游戏，我在梦里上床睡觉，做了另一个梦。

39745947.review:
Подозревая поломку ноутбука, ждёшь выходного несколько дней, чтобы отнести нерабочий кусок пластика в сервисный центр. Хорошенько проспавшись, трёшь штекер ластиком и ноут начинает работать как и прежде. Но что это, кто-то разбирал машинку и забыл подключить клавиатуру и одну платку оперативки. Надо поправить. Затем запускаешь необходимое, почти забытое за эти дни, ПО, там ложишься в кровать. Гуляя по черноте, подсознательно видишь силует обезьяны, выполненный в стиле каких-нибудь ацтеков. Чернота замкнута, ты свободен выбирать бесконечно закольцованный путь из множества бесконечно закольцованных путей, но только один из них приведёт тебя, куда надо. Собирая толпу женщин с безумными глазами, открываешь один шкаф, второй, третий, красные глаза смотрят на тебя, а затем гильотина не спасает положения, и приходится щипать за себя за нос, чтобы пробудиться от этого кошмара. Чёрт возьми, зачем всё это, всё это лишено смысла и вгоняет в тоску - думаешь ты, ложась в кровать. Снова двери, нужно выбрать одну из них, может быть там что-то более осмысленное. Выбираешь, снова перед тобой чёрная бесконечность, затем не менее бесконечный лес, шоссе, мосты над бездной. Бредёшь вперёд по канализационной трубе, понимая, что путь назад может быть куда более полезным. Хотя, какая польза, когда тебя уже съедает большая красная голова и ты оказываешься на деревянном пирсе, с которого никак не можешь выбраться. Голова съедает тебя снова, снова, затем опять. Наверное, пора просыпаться, но стойте-ка... Оказывается, ты можешь моментально отрастить волосы, перекраситься из шатенки в блондинку или отрезать себе голову. Отрезанная голова пусть и не такая быстрая, как полная версия твоего тела, но выглядит гораздо круче. Зачем? Почему всё это? Пятирукая девочка пляшет по экрану, облизывая длинным тонким языком свой левый глаз. Интрига. Зачарование. Что же дальше, интересно? Целый час прошёл, а ты всё топчешься на месте. Давай же, дерзай, снова ложись в кровать.

(Игра играет с подсознанием, помещает вас будто в тёмную незнакомую комнату, заваленную кирпичами. Возможно, разжижает мозг и всё остальное. Ознакомиться очень советую, проходить - даже не знаю, проходится ли она вообще. Можно и на ютубе поиграть, эффект примерно такой же, как от собственных похождений. Не советую играть в больном состоянии, вероятны приступы тошноты)
