39720746.review:
This game is a weird case. Gameplay wise, it's poor. You get easily stuck. It's repetitive. There are no map, no landmarks and you're given no directions. It's pretty hard to understand what to do. Exploring and going round in circles over and over can get old pretty fast. Yet... yet I would still recommend playing this game.

The gameplay is bad, but somehow it's fitting. This game is basically an endless nightmarish dream. There is no real combat and nothing that makes real sense. You're just walking in surreal landscapes, meeting absurd creatures and exploring impossible geometries. The soundtrack is ominous and very atmospheric.

Playing this game is the closest thing to experiencing an actual dream that I've felt in a video game. I don't think anything should be rationalized. I don't think you should theorize about what's actually going on in the game and I don't think you should try to find hidden sense and metaphors in what you'll be seeing either. This game is simply to be experienced, and it's one hell of an experience.

39719361.review:
En 2013, una amiga cercana me introdujó al mundo de los "indie horror game" con el juego Ib. Cuando lo terminé, me encantó y le pregunté sobre otros juegos similares y me habló de "Mad Father", "The Witch House" y finalmente "Yume Nikki", el cual jugué un año despues al ver que cumplia 10 años (No, no es plajio de Undertale :v)

Debo ser sincero. Al principio, me parecio raro el hecho que no pudiera hablar con otros personajes (principalmente Poniko). Y el final me dejó un sentimiento que no podria explicar.

Entonces empecé a buscar en Google algo mas acerca del juego, y cuando descubrí y leí las teorias locas sobre los padres de Madotsuki, su "no nacido" hijo y su sindrome "TRAP" (por mencionar algunas), me sentí mas interesado en YUME NIKKI y no por las teorias, sino por la forma interpretativa que cada persona le dá al juego.

Ya no era solo las graficas, el que causara miedo o hicierá parecer que KIKIYAMA no terminó el juego. Era lo que la gente reflejaba con su interpretación, lo que el mismo KIKIYAMA trataba de decirnos sin palabras, y lo que descubria e interpretaba cada vez que lo jugaba.

Por todo eso lo recomiendo.

39717960.review:
I only spent 6 hours beating this game, and I had to use the wiki to get probably half of the effects, but this has still become one of my favorite experiences with a game of all time.

I've known about Yume Nikki for so long that I can't even remember where I first heard about it. I'd tried to get into it prior to the steam release at least twice, but if you know this game you know that it's extremely difficult to penetrate. People will tell you to play this game blind -- don't. By all means, get as far as you can without guidance, but i'd imagine that it would be extremely difficult and tedious to get all of the effects by just wandering around. Certain areas (like the infinite wilderness) can be exceedingly obtuse when it comes to progressing or seeing the full extent of the location. Think of it as like using a tour guide on your trip through the game: although the focus is exploration, there's no harm in being directed towards what to explore. Going in blind would probably mean missing out on tons of secret events (FACE, Uboa, Mars) that really make the game as special as it is.

This game is absolutely not for everyone. If you like things like: psychological horror, surrealist art, games without objectives, games with complex interlocking worlds, or any of the numerous games which have stated Yume Nikki as a direct influence (Doki Doki Literature Club, LISA, Undertale, OFF, .flow, etc.), then you should really consider playing this game. It's a japanese game from 2004 basically released on 2channel without any fanfare that went on to become one of the most influential indie games of all time. 

The creator, Kikiyama, stopped updating the game years ago, and many on the net assumed that they had died because of the complete lack of any information on them. Nobody knows their age, whether they've worked on any other games, or even their gender. They released the game, updated it a few times, and left before it got successful. With the announcement of YUME NIKKI -DREAM DIARY-, Kikiyama has returned to direct another game and we finally know that they're alive after a literal decade of radio silence. Needless to say, this is absolutely monumental for fans of the franchise, and even if the new game sucks, it's still crazy to think that the series has been reignited after it had already been collectively decided that Kikiyama would probably never return to the internet to even update their website, let alone create a new entry in the Yume Nikki series.

This is one of very few games that I think left a lasting impact on me. There isn't even any dialogue in this thing, but it's so unique and evocative and confusing that I can't even believe that something like it exists as perfectly as it does. I'd recommend to at least give it an extended try regardless of whether you think you'll like it or not; spend a while in each of the starting rooms, read the wiki a bit, and just make an attempt to get into it. It's difficult, but the reward was more than worth it.

39699087.review:
Bueno, Yume Nikki, un “juego” ya para este punto considerado como de culto, un humilde juego hecho en Game Maker 2003 por un programador Japones conocido como [b]Kikiyama[/b].

[h1]INTRODUCCIÓN[/h1]
La protagonista de este juego se llama Madotsuki, una chica que vive sola en un recóndito apartamento, donde lo único que hay es una consola de juegos, un balcón, una cama y un escritorio donde escribe entradas en su “Diario de Sueños”. Por alguna razón no puedes salir de este apartamento, ya que cada vez que lo intentas; Madotsuki solo se negará a salir. Pero he aquí el detalle, si te vas a dormir, entraras en una dimensión distinta a la realidad, al principio todo se verá igual, aun estarás en tu cuarto, pero esta vez podrás salir, y te toparas con una gran sala en la cual hay distintas puertas, y cada puerta lleva a un extraño lugar, cada uno más raro que el anterior.

[h1]JUGABILIDAD[/h1]
La jugabilidad en Yume Nikki es muy sencilla, solo te mueves, recoges “efectos” y realizas una acción; Los efectos son distintos cambios en las características de Madotsuki los cuales te permitirán realizar ciertas cosas a medida que exploras el extraño mundo de los sueños, desde simplemente tener el cabello más largo hasta cambiar de forma enteramente. Puedes obtener un total de 24 efectos en todo el juego los cuales te ayudarán a descubrir mas cosas o entrar a otros lugares.

[b]EL FACTOR MUNDO ABIERTO[/b]
Esta es la gran fortaleza de Yume Nikki pero al mismo tiempo puede ser algo que actue en su desventaja. Detrás de cada puerta hay un mundo distinto por explorar, y a pesar de las cosas que puedes ver en dichos mundos como personajes extraños, o fondos alucinantes, e incluso en algunos casos perturbadores y aterradores, en algunos de estos mundos pasa que se siente tan abierto que terminas perdiéndote, esto es bueno pero a la vez malo, ya que se da un espacio grande en el cual tienes que buscar algo muy pequeño (Generalmente efectos) y si por ejemplo continuas caminando en una dirección eventualmente volverás al punto inicial, ya que puedes seguir caminando indefinidamente, sin embargo el mundo se repite, al ser tan abierto pasan 2 cosas, la primera es que debido a que el campo visual es algo limitado no sabes a donde ir, y la segunda es que para poder orientarte te limitas a contar tus pasos o el tiempo que lleves caminando en X dirección para luego tomar Y Dirección, lo cual puede volver la exploración bastante aburrida, sobre todo que en algunos mundos no pasa absolutamente nada, es un gran espacio sin nada que hacer, salvo por algún pasaje secreto o algún personaje que te encuentres que te teletransporte a otro sitio, la idea es buscar y encontrar, sin embargo no tienes ningún tipo de guía. Algunos efectos te ayudan en ciertas zonas, ya sea para poder ver mejor o simplemente ir mas rápido, pero nunca sabrás donde está cada cosa a menos de que vayas explorando y “a lo que salga” o que busques una guía en Linea para que sepas que tienes que hacer. Y hablando de eso último, ¿Cuál es el objetivo de este juego para empezar?, es un juego de exploración y no parece tener ningun objetivo en particular.

[h1]CONCLUSÍON[/h1]
Yume Nikki es un juego en el que tienes que perderte y eventualmente sabrás que hacer, a pesar de lo críptico que pueda llegar a ser, ya que no sabes que hacer, como hacerlo, donde hacerlo y por que, simplemente estas a la deriba, aunque... el juego si tiene un final.

[h1]VEREDICTO[/h1]
[b]0/0 - ¿?.[/b] Ya se lo que están pensando al ver ese número [b]"¿Estás Diciendo que es malo?"[/b] Y tal vez los que defiendan este “juego” a capa y espada [b]“¿COMO TE ATREVES A INSULTAR A YUME NIKKI, EL MEJOR JUEGO DE TODOS LOS TIEMPOS? MALDITO BASTARDO HIJO DE P-“[/b], yo solo les digo: [b]“No” y “Calmense, no he insultado a nada ni a nadie[/b]” respectivamente. Yume Nikki es un juego bastante críptico, y hasta inentendible en ocasiones, tiene aspectos muy buenos como el construir muy buenas atmosferas de desolación soledad o incluso terror, sin embargo, es un juego en el que definitivamente no sabes que estás haciendo, solo lo haces.
Yume Nikki es un juego muy raro, no es recomendable para cualquiera, en el sentido de que no cualquiera lo entiende (Entre esos yo, en parte por lo menos), aunque tengo que admitirlo... puede llegar a ser muy interesante si te gustan las cosas fuera de lo común.

I'd heard a lot about Yume Nikki before it came on steam but I always had trouble getting it to run. Now that it's finally working, I can say it truly deserves its cult classic status. Yume Nikki manages to marry very disparate themes and mechanics in ways that rarely work for other games. It manages to combine open environments with very little interactivity with unique enough visuals that I still feel like I'm exploring and progressing. 39671512.review:
i experienced yume nikki way back in high school when i was a sophomore; i was in pure wonderment over the game because of how it mystified me & probed my curiosity to explore what i felt was very mysterious at the time- the theories / interpretations of the game kept me on the edge of my seat. i really loved that it was a game where you could come up with your own ideas of what's truly going on & that everyone's experience would be vastly varied

now that i'm much older i understand how this game could be really boring for many people since the majority of what you do is explore the nexus with no clear-cut goals in mind. but honestly, i like that it's not linear & feels open world in some sense, because that is how everyone's experience can be different person to person.

i haven't touched yume nikki in years, having it here on steam is so refreshing & i'm still very thankful for kikiyama's work as it inspired me to make concepts & ideas for games & it also came into my life during the time that i became heavily invested in dreams.

i recommend this game because of the emotional value i have placed on it, but i understand that it's not a game for everyone. even so, take a moment to experience the game on your own terms if you can!

39670264.review:
In a way, Yume Nikki could be described as a walking simulator. Unlike more recent examples of this genre, however, Yume Nikki at no point tries to shove some heavy-handed plot down your throat - quite on the contrary, the game goes out of its way -not- to tell you what its all about, leaving you wide-eyed and asking yourself what in the hells is going on as you explore an interconnected labyrinth of dreamworlds that range from psychodelic neon-colored visions to nightmarish,

While raw gameplay is not exactly the strongest point of the Yume Nikki (you will spend a lot of time searching for objects hidden in otherwise sparesely equipped levels which also loop), the sheer sense of wonder when you someone stumble upon a path to a new level or encounter one of the randomly occuring special events generally makes it worth it. Rest assured, Rest assured, drawing your own map to keep track of how the various different places in the game link to each other is highly encouraged.

But perhaps this lack of "proper" gameplay is exactly what makes Yume Nikki shine even today, 14 years after its original release - the game is proverbially timeless. Unless you want to spoil your experience by reading one of the many available online guides, the surreal egghunt of Yume Nikki is very much still worth it.

39669061.review:
Yume Nikki é genial, ousado e viciante. Você assume a personagem principal, Madotsuki, que mantem o hábito de descrever seus sonhos em um diário, e nesta proposta você explora seus diversos mundos oníricos. O objetivo do jogo é coletar todos os "efeitos", porém a maior parte da experiência é a de percorrer todas as camadas e sentir a atmosfera, a combinação da trilha sonora com as cenas dos sonhos e demais personagens, mergulhar no universo mais íntimo de Madotsuki. Como não possui diálogos ou explicações, a maior incitação para continuar jogando é a curiosidade.

Sem dúvidas, será chato para quem não tem interesse em desvendar cada sonho, mas para os que estiverem, uma experiência singular os aguarda.

39631613.review:
(Time Played doesn't reflect my actual time spent in the game, I've been playing this game for years.)

Yume Nikki is a game that is immensely important to me. The true meaning of the game is completely left up to your own interpretation, as it's an exploration game in its purest form. There is no real "goal," and yet each time you play you can find something new. There's a reason this game is such a beloved cult-classic.

This is a game that has oftentimes helped me cope with my depression. The atmosphere can't really be explained, there's a loneliness and beauty present that you just have to experience for yourself. The art, music, and character designs all contribute to this. This game is one of my biggest inspirations, especially artistically.

I don't normally write reviews on Steam, but this game is so important to me that I felt like I had to say something! I'm so happy that new people are going to get to experience it.

I highly, HIGHLY, recommend playing Yume Nikki. Set a few hours aside, get comfortable, grab some snacks, and enjoy.
